Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Expectation2: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation2: The carpenter should maintain a clean and organized work area
Story: I was sweeping up sawdust in the workshop, the hum of the table saw still echoing in my ears, when my phone buzzed in my pocket. I glanced at the screen and saw a message from Jamie: “Had the worst day. Everything feels pointless.” I knew what that meant—Jamie needed me to listen, to be there, to offer the kind of support only a close friend could give. But as I reached for my phone, I noticed a pile of wood scraps dangerously close to the edge of the workbench. I remembered the foreman’s warning just this morning: “Keep your area clean, or someone’s going to get hurt.” My hands itched to text Jamie back, to let them know I cared, but I could almost hear the clatter of falling boards and the sharp reprimand if I let my guard down. I stood there, phone in one hand, broom in the other, torn between being the friend Jamie needed and the responsible carpenter I was expected to be. My heart pounded as I weighed the risks, feeling the pressure of both worlds closing in.
